entry.title: Top 10 SAP Cloud ALM News September 2025
entry.content:
Get ready to discover the latest enhancements in SAP Cloud ALM for September! This month, we're thrilled to present our TOP 10 Features, with six exciting updates for implementation and four powerful improvements for operations. These innovations are designed to streamline your application lifecycle management processes and boost your productivity.

Let’s dive into the newest tools and functionalities that will revolutionize the way you work with SAP Cloud ALM.

 

IMPLEMENTATION UPDATES

1. Enhanced Document Management in Solution Activities

When accessing the details of a solution activity in the Solution Activities list, you can now see information about any Documents that are assigned to it. In addition to the document's title, the technical ID, status, and the project for which it was created are also displayed. Moreover, after switching to Edit mode, you can directly Assign or Unassign documents for the selected solution activity within this list.

Note

  • The name of the document is an active link, allowing you to call it up in the Documents app directly. 
  • If any details are hidden due to your screen resolution or layout, choose the  (Show More per Row) icon to view all document details.

 

 

2. Streamlined Document Creation from Templates in Processes App

The Processes app now offers a more efficient way to create documents within the solution process viewer section. Instead of always starting from scratch, users have the option to create a new document based on an existing template. As before, when users select Create > Document, they are redirected to the Documents app, but now they can either click theicon to access a list of available document templates or choose Continue to create a document from scratch. Once the document is completed, users are automatically returned to the Processes app.

 

3. New Tag Filter Added for Improved Task Organization

The Burn Up Chart app now includes a Tag filter, allowing users to filter tasks based on specific tags. This feature refines project management by providing a more structured and effective way to track progress, making it easier to concentrate on relevant tasks and optimize the workflow.

 

4. Reassignment of Test Cases in Test Preparation

The test case editor now allows you to modify the assignment of an existing test case, enabling you to associate it with a different scope, solution process, or solution process flow diagram. This way, you can correct initial assignment errors or adapt the test case to evolving project structures without having to delete and recreate it from scratch.

 

5. Automatic Target Tenant Selection for Transport Creation

When you create a transport in the Features app, the default target tenant is automatically selected after you select a source tenant.  

 

6. Increased File Size Limit for External Files

The file size limit for external documents has been raised to 120 MB, allowing you to upload larger files and share and collaborate on more substantial documents without the need for file compression or splitting.

Caution

The upload times out after 80 seconds. If your upload speed is slow, this might cause the upload to fail.

 

OPERATIONS UPDATES

7. Improved Exceptions Page in Real User Monitoring

The Exceptions page now provides a comprehensive overview of user-related exceptions specific to the chosen application and scope. Users can access a detailed description of each exception by clicking on the corresponding exception icon and get displayed relevant context information. This feature enables the users to quickly identify and investigate exceptions impacting their applications.

The Real User Monitoring app currently covers: 

  • ABAP Dumps 
  • ABAP Web Service Exceptions 
  • ABAP Gateway Errors

 

8. New System & Instance Heartbeat Monitoring Feature

The ABAP Heartbeat Monitoring feature enables ABAP systems and instances to transmit a heartbeat metric at one-minute intervals. This metric serves as a vital sign, allowing for quick detection of any system downtime or issues with metric transmission. By continuously monitoring the heartbeat, the feature helps ensure the smooth operation and reliability of ABAP systems.

Note

A negative response is only an indication that the system or instance is unavailable but doesn't definitively confirm it.

 

9. Available Job End Time and Run Time in Run Info

The alert notification email now includes additional run details in the Run Info section, such as the End Time and Run Duration. This is an improvement from the previous version, which only provided the Start Time, making it challenging to quickly determine the total execution time. With the addition of End Time and Run Duration, you can now easily assess the job's runtime directly from the notification email, without the need for further investigation.

 

10. Comprehensive SAP Intelligent Agriculture Monitoring

With this new feature, users can track and oversee master data messages within SAP Intelligent Agriculture. The system provides a comprehensive status summary of both incoming and outgoing messages. Additionally, users can drill down to single messages to check individual issues and message details.

---------------------------------------------------

Stay tuned for future editions where we'll continue to unveil the latest advancements and improvements in SAP Cloud ALM for implementation and operations

In the meantime, we encourage you to delve into the SAP Help Portal and seize the opportunity to transform your business. Embrace the power of SAP Cloud ALM and embark on a journey towards excellence! 🚀

entry.title: Re: Story Changes Lost in Edit Mode Due to Active Bookmar...
entry.content:
Hi RajuRao

I understand that it can be challenging, especially if you are unable to create tickets and get support or clarification from SAP about specific functions. Since I’m not currently in that situation myself, I can’t share personal experience with it.

However, I did submit a ticket to SAP about a similar case where filter values were not updated when using bookmarks.

According to the response I received, this behavior is “working as designed.”  In OSE, bookmarks save the state of all story elements (if that option is selected) at the time the bookmark is created. This means that if elements in the story are later changed, the bookmark will still load the original version of those elements. As a result, the story may not reflect the latest updates. In one of our cases,  users even encountered errors because some elements had been removed from the story, but the bookmark still attempted to load them.

Please find below a more detailed explanation from SAP:
___________________________________________________
If Bookmark Panel setting is "All Components in the Story"  or story filters and/or Chart widgets are checked in “Selected Components Only“ (or “State Changed Components Only” and change the story at view time), 
and
After one bookmark is created, users open the original story in edit time, and change and save the story (add new story filter/add new story filter member/change Chart widget style), and then, users apply the created bookmark and find that changed story filter/Table filter is reverted.

Then this behavior is by design. As you mentioned, this gives the impression that bookmarks “lock” the story in an outdated state. This is the idea of optimized story bookmark- replace story widget using the bookmarked one.

This is because
1. All "story filters" (for the whole story) are treated as one component, and
2. Each chart widget (including widget-level style settings) is treated as one component.

In the current SAC optimized story bookmark design, if one component is in “Selected Components Only“ (or “State Changed Components Only” and changed at view time, or users use "All Components in the Story"), this component (story filters, or Chart widget, or other supported widgets) will be captured and saved into bookmark content. The captured content contains all related properties. The captured content will be saved in the SAC backend database. When you apply the bookmark, the whole component will be replaced by the bookmark content (whether the component is changed or not, bookmark content will be used). 

In your case, you do not want to change story filter/chart using bookmark. You can configure optimized story bookmark feature to do not capture story filter/chart widget. So, changed story filters/Chart widgets can keep those changes after the bookmark is applied. You can unselect story filters/Table widgets in “Selected Components Only“ (and re-save bookmarks). It means bookmark saving process will skip those unselected components - so, applying bookmark will not affect those unselected components.

Steps:
1. Open story in edit mode
2. Click toolbar "View" -> "Left Side Panel" button to show the Outline on the left side.
3. In the Outline, click "Global Settings"->"Bookmarks" to open the right side bookmark panel.
4. In the right bookmark panel, click "Selected Components Only"
5. Click "Selected Components" button to open the dialog to choose widgets.
6. Users can select some widgets, and unselected some widgets. Only selected widgets will be added to bookmark content. So, if users do not want to bookmark one widget (for example, story filter, or one Chart widget), just make sure it is unselected in the dialog.
7. Click "OK" to close the dialog, and then save the story, and create new bookmarks. Only newly created bookmark will apply changed settings (existing bookmark content will not be changed)."
___________________________________________________

In our case we have implemented the proposed solution and restricted which elements are allowed to be bookmarked. 

I hope this explanation can be helpfull to others.

entry.title: Re: Dunning per Mail/Printing only if there is no Mail-Ad...
entry.content:
Hello Chris,

unfortunately not. If i have the settings like this: 

Output TypeRoleAccount TypeDefault Email AddressChannelExclusive Indicator
=DUNN_NOTICE  is not initialEMAILX
=DUNN_NOTICE   PRINT 

SAP creates only an E-Mail when there is a mail address in the BP master Data, which is correct. But if there is no mail address, no mail AND no print is created.

When i choose the settings like this:

Output TypeRoleAccount TypeDefault Email AddressChannelExclusive Indicator
=DUNN_NOTICE  is not initialEMAIL-
=DUNN_NOTICE   PRINT 

SAP prints ONLY when there is no mail address (which is good). But when there is a mail address, SAP prints AND sends a mail.

So it is not 100% right.....

Kind regards

entry.title: Re: SAP Build Work Zone Security
entry.content:
Hi @ROHITGERA1,

correct: SAP Cloud Identity Services contains the parts IAS (Identity Authentication Service) and IPS (Identity Provisioning Service). More specifically, it also contains the Identity Directory (persistence of users) and Authorization Management.

All these sub-services are accessed through one single URL. You find multiple tiles corresopnding to the different parts of CLoud Identity Services when opening the main URL.

The SCIM API (see https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/System_for_Cross-domain_Identity_Management for an explanation of SCIM) is a standardized protocol to exchange user identities. IPS can use this API but you can also use the API prgrammatically from your own application, for example to get a list of users in a specific group.

Best, Martin

entry.title: How to exclude safety stock from MRP when demand exists, but include it when no demand exists?
entry.content:
Hello Experts,

I need some guidance on the following requirement from our client.

In our current SAP setup, with MRP Type: PD and Stgy:40 , MRP is considering demand + safety stock together. For example:

  • Sales Order = 1000

  • Safety Stock = 500

  • Available Stock = 0

  • System Proposal = 1500

However, our business requires the following behavior:

  1. When demand exists (SO or PIR): System should only generate proposals for the demand (e.g., 1000), ignoring safety stock.

  2. When there is no demand or If demand is less than Safety stock: System should generate proposals only for the safety stock (e.g., 500).

Is there any standard configuration (like MRP type setting or MRP group) to achieve this requirement, or do we need to use any enhancement ?

Thanks in advance for your guidance.

entry.title: Re: Manual GL Account Assignment for Billing Transactions
entry.content:
Hello @cgimena 

Sorry for the delayed reply. Yes, this also relates to Accounts Receivable. In S/4HANA Public Cloud, the reconciliation account for both customers and suppliers is sourced from the BP master and cannot be changed in operational documents, such as Create Supplier Invoice, PO-based invoices, and SD billing. This restriction preserves the integrity of the subledger G/L.

If you need to post to a different general ledger:

Use direct FI postings. Post General Journal Entries for pure G/L documents, not subledger items.

If account determination varies by business logic, modify automatic determination (relevant SSCUIs) or, if available, use a Cloud BAdI for billing account determination. No manual override exists for reconciliation accounts in subledger postings.

SAP Helpful documentation

SAP Help – Supplier Invoice Processing (Public Cloud)

SAP Learning: Maintaining Business Partner Master Data

SAP Help – Automatic Account Determination (Public Cloud)

Let me know if you need further support

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: PLM Tech Uncovered: SAP Integrated Product Development Update 09/2025
entry.content:
Hello and welcome to the September 2025 edition of this blog series! I'm happy to share the newest features of SAP Integrated Product Development with you, so let's get started right away:

General
Navigate to apps in SAP Integrated Product Development using Joule
You can navigate to all apps in SAP Integrated Product Development by asking Joule to open them. Users can open the requested apps using the button in Joule’s response, provided they have authorization to access them.

Collaboration
Use Joule to generate summaries for documents
You can use Joule to generate summaries for documents uploaded in the My Collaborations app.

Specification Management
Load data from external systems
Specification Management offers a hybrid solution for data integration with SAP S/4HANA systems. With the help of this functionality, you can load specification object content from an SAP S/4HANA specification to a SAP Integrated Product Development specification.
Default inheritance template for creating specifications
You can select a default inheritance template per specification type in the Specification Types app. This default template is then used to create specifications when you choose “Create with Inheritance” in the Manage Specifications app.
Clear phrase value from attribute fields to empty state
If you enter a phrase value for a property, you can now clear the value.

Visualization
Auto detection of hotspots in P&ID drawings
You can automatically generate hotspots from 2D Drawings that contain piping and instrumentation diagram.

🔔 To stay informed until the next update you can:
✏️  Subscribe to the What’s New Viewer on SAP Integrated Product Development Help Portal https://url.sap/5nbm4a
🔗Join our LinkedIn group SAP Solutions for PLM https://www.linkedin.com/groups/9257139/
🌐  Visit us at www.sap.com/IPD

📢💡 By the way, do you know how to provide feedback for SAP Integrated Product Development?
➡️  Watch this video to find out how and send your feedback directly from the application. We always look forward to hearing from you!

entry.title: Re: SAP B1 IR/GR 8% threshold, invoice/credit posting
entry.content:
Hi Tom,

I am not aware of such system control that allows you to set acceptable deviation percentage between GRPO and AP Invoice. I believe this is a custom setup, most likely done via stored procedure control where amount on AP invoice is compared to amount of it's base GRPO document.

You should be able to change this, but it might be best to discuss it with your partner who implemented this, they should know the reason behind it.

In general, you absolutely can add AP invoice with amount different than its base GRPO. If this is Item type document and the goods are received to the warehouse via GRPO, you can add AP invoice which will automatically recalculate the value of received goods. Should go like this:

1. Purchase order for 800€.

2. GRPO for 800€ (usually just copied from PO, warehouse operators don't usually deal with price differences)

3. AP Invoice for 2400€

3a. If the goods are still in warehouse when you create AP Invoice, value will be changed to the one on AP invoice (in your case value will increase by 1600€)

3b. If the goods are not available anymore (sold or issued to production), value will not be changed but the difference will be posted to separate price difference account.

entry.title: Re: SAP Public Cloud / Problem with the Migration of Cont...
entry.content:
UPDATE: After some research we found a solution to this problem. The first app you need is "Import Master Data - BP Relationships" (F6552A). There you can download example files that can be used for the import. Within the file "BREL_Simple_Create" you can add the two business partners that you want to establish the relationship for. You also need to add the type of relationship, in my case "BUR001" for the contact person relationship. After that its just a simple upload.
In the app "Manage Mass Creation Processes - BP Relationships (Version 2)" (F6560A) you can now create a process based on this import and validate the imported data and finaly import it into the system.

entry.title: A Hitchhiker's Guide to SAP Fiori User Experience and its Technologies – 2025 edition
entry.content:
I’m sure you’ve heard of SAP Fiori, the design system for all SAP products. SAP Fiori covers the design itself, the SAP Fiori applications delivered by SAP, but also technologies and tools to run those apps, to extend standard SAP apps or even to develop your own custom apps.

  • Are you looking for a high-level understanding of SAP Fiori and its technologies and tools?
  • Would you like to get an overview to see how all of this fits together?
  • Do you know which role SAP Build plays?
  • You have an ABAP / on-prem background and want to learn about how SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) / cloud is used for SAP Fiori?
  • Do you want to leverage entry points for your own practical learning, e.g. recommended tutorials?

Look no further. This 2-part webinar helps and provides entry points for your hands-on learning.

Agenda Part 1

SAP Fiori is the User Experience of SAP Business Suite that changes the way you work. In this overview you’ll get a first understanding of SAP Fiori: The SAP Fiori design system and how it is realized with the related UI technologies and tools, for business users, key users, and developers. This part covers the main environments like SAP S/4HANA and SAP Business Technology Platform. The overview extends to the actual productive usage of SAP Fiori business applications via an SAP Fiori launchpad, and the essential UI frameworks.

  • The SAP Fiori Design system
  • An overview of Technologies and Tools for SAP Fiori
  • The entry point to SAP Fiori: SAP Build Work Zone
  • The strategic UI frameworks SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori elements

Agenda Part 2

In the second part we’ll cover SAP Build for AI–based application development and, of course, look at ABAP development tools. This leads us to the important scenario of extensibility and how you can easily add custom extension to standard SAP apps. Mobile technologies and a Q&A section close the second part.

  • The SAP Build development environment and ABAP Development Tools in Eclipse
  • Extending standard SAP applications with Clean Core principles
  • Technologies for a mobile experience

Who Should Attend?

This overview session is for everyone, from executives to software developers. It is a complete run-through of SAPs user experience technologies, ranging from end user personalization to developer tools, from creating an initial project to productively using an app. This content is especially useful if you have an ABAP background and need a sound overview understanding of SAP Fiori and its tools and technologies. The webinar has a focus on providing the full picture and entry points into further learnings.

👉 Join me for this 2-part webinar, live on October 28. and 30., 17:00 – 18:00 CET on YouTube Part 1 and Part 2.

entry.title: 🚀 SAP BTP Weekly: ¿Estamos listos para dejar que la IA ejecute nuestros procesos?
entry.content:
1. Joule Studio y agentes de IA en procesos SAP

SAP anunció que Joule Studio será generalmente disponible en junio de 2025 como entorno integrado en SAP Build para construir habilidades (skills) y agentes de IA que ejecutan workflows complejos. Los desarrolladores podrán diseñar agentes que actúen con contexto de negocio en procesos, no solo tareas puntuales. La Integration Suite sumará capacidades de recomendación automática y predicción de anomalías en API calls. Esto reduce código repetitivo y acelera la automatización contextual. Pero la gobernanza será clave para evitar “cajas negras”.

Ventajas :

 

  • Acelera el desarrollo de procesos inteligentes.
  • Mejora la eficiencia operativa con agentes en tiempo real.
  • Incrementa la trazabilidad y capacidad de respuesta.

 

🔗 Más información

¿Dejarías que un agente autónomo ejecute decisiones operativas en tu organización?

2. SAP Build Process Automation con IA generativa

SAP Build Process Automation incorpora IA generativa para que usuarios de negocio diseñen flujos sin necesidad de código. Un CFO o analista puede describir un proceso en lenguaje natural y el sistema genera el flujo base. Arquitectos y desarrolladores ajustan la lógica para robustecerlo. Esto acelera la entrega de valor en procesos clave. El reto será equilibrar agilidad con gobernanza y control.

Ventajas :

 

  • Democratiza la automatización para áreas de negocio.
  • Reduce tiempos de entrega de procesos digitales.
  • Fomenta colaboración entre negocio y tecnología.

 

🔗 Más información

¿Confiarías en que áreas de negocio creen flujos críticos con IA generativa?

3. SAP Business Network sobre SAP BTP

La red de colaboración SAP Business Network se integra más fuerte a BTP. Esto habilita trazabilidad, compliance e IA nativos en la red. Los procesos con proveedores y compradores ganan sincronía. Pero aumenta la complejidad de gobernanza y onboarding de socios. La adopción depende también de la madurez de cada partner.

Ventajas :

 

  • Mayor transparencia en la cadena de suministro.
  • Procesos más ágiles entre múltiples organizaciones.
  • Cumplimiento normativo más fácil de demostrar.

 

🔗 Más información

¿Extenderías procesos críticos a tu red de socios usando BTP?

4. Innovaciones de AI en SAP Integration Suite

Integration Suite ahora sugiere mapas de integración y detecta conflictos automáticamente. Se anuncia un “adaptador AI” para conectar LLM externos. Esto acelera los ciclos de integración con recomendaciones en tiempo real. Permite prever consumos de API y anticipar cuellos de botella. Los equipos deberán validar sugerencias de la IA para asegurar calidad.

Ventajas :

 

  • Reduce tiempos de desarrollo y testing.
  • Anticipa problemas antes de que impacten la operación.
  • Facilita integraciones complejas con IA como copiloto.

 

🔗 Más información

¿Confiarías en una IA para diseñar mapas de integración productivos?

5. Estrategia “Clean Core + extensibilidad con BTP”

La idea central es mantener el core SAP estándar y mover extensiones a BTP. Esto evita deuda técnica y facilita upgrades en el core. Implica rediseñar límites entre procesos estándar y diferenciadores. Las extensiones requieren su propia gobernanza y testing. Es un cambio cultural y técnico importante.

Ventajas :

 

  • Facilita actualizaciones del core.
  • Permite innovar sin comprometer estabilidad.
  • Reduce costos de mantenimiento a largo plazo.

 

🔗 Más información

¿Tu empresa ya avanza hacia un core limpio o aún lo ves lejano?

6. Gobernanza de datos en entornos BTP híbridos

La mezcla de datos SAP y no SAP en BTP exige un modelo de gobierno sólido. Es clave definir roles, propiedad y calidad del dato maestro. La replicación entre entornos puede generar inconsistencias si no se diseña bien. Se deben cumplir regulaciones locales y globales de privacidad. El lineage del dato será un diferenciador en auditorías.

Ventajas :

 

  • Mayor confianza en reportes y decisiones.
  • Cumplimiento más sencillo ante auditorías.
  • Reducción de duplicaciones e inconsistencias.

 

🔗 Más información

¿Preferís un modelo único de datos o múltiples vistas según área de negocio?

7. Adopción de BTP en industrias reguladas

Industrias reguladas exigen trazabilidad, certificaciones y seguridad extrema. SAP NS2 propone un marco específico para implementar BTP en estos entornos. Esto incluye segregación de ambientes y auditoría constante. El cumplimiento requiere alineación entre IT, compliance y negocio. No todas las regulaciones están actualizadas al modelo cloud.

Ventajas :

 

  • Confianza de auditores y entes reguladores.
  • Menor riesgo legal y reputacional.
  • Innovación cloud en sectores tradicionalmente rígidos.

 

🔗 Más información

¿Usarías BTP en procesos críticos de tu industria regulada o solo para innovación?

entry.title: (RAP/Fiori) Currency Annotation/Formatting Not Applied for Action with Parameters in Fiori UI
entry.content:
Hello everyone,

I'm encountering a specific issue where a currency field in a Fiori Elements UI is not being formatted correctly, but only when it's part of a parameter dialog for an parameter action.

The Problem:

I have an action that requires parameters, including an Amount and a Currency Code. In my abstract CDS view, I've set up the standard annotations to link the amount field to its corresponding currency code field, like this:




On the UI, when the action dialog opens, the 'Amount' field should automatically adjust its display and validation based on the selected currency. For instance, it should enforce two decimal places for currencies like USD or EUR, and zero for currencies like JPY or KRW.

The key issue is the lack of decimal place conversion. For example, if the currency is set to 'USD', entering a value of 100 is not automatically interpreted or displayed as 100.00. The UI treats it as a simple number, failing to apply the correct currency-specific precision.

This same annotation works perfectly for fields on our main List Report and Object Pages, but it seems to fail specifically within the context of an action's parameter dialog. I've already confirmed that both the amount and currency values are correctly passed in the OData payload.

Has anyone else faced this issue? Is there a known limitation or a different approach required for applying currency annotations to action parameters?

Any help or insight would be greatly appreciated.



Dear

@Andre_Fischer  
@MioYasutake 

I was wondering if you might have come across this specific behavior before. My apologies for the direct mention, but any insight you could provide would be incredibly helpful.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Stakeholderanalyse in SAP-Projekten: Praxiserprobte Methoden und wertvolle Erfahrungen
entry.content:
Die September-Ausgabe der SAP Kaffee Ecke widmete sich einem zentralen Erfolgsfaktor für SAP-Transformationen: der systematischen Stakeholderanalyse. Holly Hammerton, Leiterin des Digital Change and Adoption Teams bei SAP und erfahrene Psychologin, teilte ihre praktischen Erfahrungen und bewährten Methoden mit den Teilnehmenden.Stakeholderanalyse als Erfolgsfaktor verstehen

Die Eingangsbefragung zeigte bereits die Relevanz des Themas: Über 60 Prozent der Teilnehmenden verfügten über Erfahrungen mit Stakeholderanalysen. In der gemeinsamen Wortwolke zur Frage, welche Themen oder Aspekte die Teilnehmenden typischerweise in einer Stakeholderanalyse analysieren, kristallisierten sich schnell die wichtigsten Aspekte heraus - von Einfluss und Motivation über Rollen und Verantwortlichkeiten bis hin zu Transformationszielen und Change-Erfahrungen.

Holly eröffnete ihre Präsentation mit einer lehrreichen Anekdote aus ihrer frühen Beraterzeit. In einem Projekt hatte sie sich zu stark auf die Einschätzung der Projektleitung verlassen und dabei einen hierarchisch scheinbar unbedeutsamen, aber faktisch sehr einflussreichen Bereichsleiter übersehen. Dieser verzögerte das Projekt daraufhin erheblich, da der Vorstand vollständig auf seine Expertise vertraute. "Wie hätten wir das vermeiden können? Indem ich eine ordentliche Stakeholderanalyse durchgeführt hätte - und zwar nicht nur aus Perspektive der Projektleitung", resümierte sie.

WIESO Stakeholderanalysen in SAP-Transformationen entscheidend sind

Stakeholder in SAP-Transformationen sind zahlreich und sehr unterschiedlich. Wenn Change Manager sie verstehen, können sie Kommunikation gezielt steuern und Risiken reduzieren. Oft scheitern Projekte daran, dass Entscheidungsträger nicht den nötigen Rückhalt geben - beispielsweise bei der Ressourcenfreigabe. Die Stakeholderanalyse hilft dabei, genau diese Personen zu identifizieren, die Unterstützung und Sponsorship sichern können.

Darüber hinaus ermöglicht sie eine passgenaue Planung von Kommunikation und Maßnahmen. "Wen habe ich vor mir und welche Wege nutze ich, um mit ihnen zu kommunizieren? Was brauchen diese Stakeholdergruppen überhaupt an Informationen und zu welchem Zeitpunkt?", fasste Holly die zentralen Fragen zusammen. Widerstände werden früh sichtbar durch die Analyse der Stakeholder-Einstellungen zum Projekt. Gleichzeitig können Multiplikatoren gezielt erkannt und genutzt werden. Die regelmäßige Überprüfung der Veränderungsbereitschaft und Wirksamkeit von Maßnahmen zeigt den Return on Investment der Stakeholderanalyse auf.

WIE kann man Stakeholderanalysen durchführen

Hollys klare Empfehlung lautet: früh beginnen und kontinuierlich aktualisieren. In SAP Projekten empfiehlt sie ein systematisches Vorgehen entlang der SAP Activate Methodik:

Bereits in der Prepare-Phase sollten erste Stakeholderanalysen durchgeführt werden, da hier schon Entscheidungsträger identifizierbar sind - auch wenn Enduser in dieser Phase noch nicht immer unbedingt bekannt sind. Analyse und Management der Stakeholder greifen dabei iterativ Hand in Hand.

Das systematische Vorgehen umfasst mehrere Schritte: Die Identifikation erfasst direkt und indirekt betroffene Stakeholder. Die Analyse erfolgt zunächst auf Gruppenebene durch Bündelung nach Bereichen oder Regionen, dann auf Individualebene für Influencer in ihren Bereichen oder zukünftige Key User. Anschließend werden Maßnahmen zum Stakeholder-Engagement abgeleitet und durchgeführt.

Regelmäßige Updates der Stakeholderanalyse - entweder zur nächsten Projektphase, zu wichtigen Projektmeilensteinen oder zu festen Zeitintervallen wie zum Beispiel alle drei Monate - stellen die Aktualität sicher. "Rinse and repeat" beschreibt den kontinuierlich wiederholten Prozess bis zum Transformationserfolg umgangssprachlich.

Bewährte Tools für die praktische Umsetzung

Die Vierfeldertafel als Herzstück

Die klassische Vierfeldertafel bildet das Herzstück der Stakeholderanalyse. Sie kategorisiert Stakeholder nach ihrem Einfluss auf das Projekt (Level of influence on project success) und ihrer Einstellung dazu (Attitude towards project). Die vier Kategorien erfordern unterschiedliche Engagement-Strategien, im Folgenden grob umschrieben:

Opponents (hoher Einfluss, negative Einstellung) erfordern erhebliche Investitionen in gezielte Aktivitäten. Erste Priorität ist es, ihre Einstellung zum Projekt zu ändern. Alternativ sollte versucht werden, ihren Einfluss auf den Projekterfolg zu reduzieren.

Promoters (hoher Einfluss, positive Einstellung) werden durch gezielte Aktionen in ihrer positiven Haltung bestärkt. Ihr Einfluss wird genutzt, um andere für das Projekt zu gewinnen, und sie werden als offizielle Sponsoren oder Multiplikatoren integriert.

Skeptics (geringer Einfluss, negative Einstellung) erhalten ausreichend Zeit und Information, um informiert zu bleiben. Besonders die Benefits des Projekts werden kommuniziert, und sie werden im Blick behalten.

Supporters (geringer Einfluss, positive Einstellung) werden ermutigt, ihren Einfluss auf das Projekt zu erhöhen, um sie auf das "Promoters"-Level zu bringen. Ihre positive Einstellung wird in ihrem jeweiligen Einflussbereich genutzt, und sie können beispielsweise gut zu Power Usern gemacht werden.

Die Stakeholder-Engagement-Aktivitäten umfassen meist verschiedene Formen von Kommunikation, Training & Enablement sowie Performance Management.

Darüber hinaus stellte Holly eine Stakeholder Analyse auf individueller Ebene vor: Eine aggregierte Sicht auf die verschiedenen Stakeholder, z. B. „Business“ vs. „IT“ können helfen, zusätzliche Erkenntnisse zu gewinnen.

Kraftfeldanalyse für tieferes Verständnis

Ergänzend empfiehlt Holly die Kraftfeldanalyse nach Kurt Lewin, um treibende und hemmende Kräfte zu verstehen, die auf individuelle Stakeholder wirken. Diese Methode ist für wichtige Stakeholder und Stakeholder-Gruppen sinnvoll, da Widerstände viele Hintergründe haben. Das Verstehen ermöglicht einem die Formulierung einer individuellen Strategie für den Umgang diesen Personen gegenüber.

Holly betonte dabei die Notwendigkeit der absoluten Vertraulichkeit aller solcher Bewertungen, da diese Art von Bewertungen in den falschen Händen verständlicherweise starke Emotionen und Reaktionen auslösen könnten.

Strukturierte Dokumentation auf Gruppenebene

Holly stellte eine praktische Excel-Vorlage für die Stakeholder-Analyse auf Gruppenebene vor. Diese kombiniert eine High-Level Impact-Analyse mit der eigentlichen Stakeholder-Analyse. Die Vorlage erfasst systematisch:

  • Stakeholder-Gruppe,
  • Standort,
  • Anzahl der Mitarbeiter,
  • Namen von Schlüsselpersonen,
  • bevorzugte Kommunikationskanäle und zusätzliche Kommentare

High Level Impact-Analyse:

  • Auswirkungen der Veränderung auf die Stakeholder-Gruppe
  • erwartete Reaktionen

Stakeholder-Analyse:

  • Fähigkeit, das Projekt zu beeinflussen
  • Einstellung zum Projekt

Diese strukturierte Herangehensweise ermöglicht es, sowohl den Change Impact als auch die Stakeholder-Dynamiken systematisch zu erfassen und daraus gezielte Maßnahmen abzuleiten.

WAS mache ich mit den Ergebnissen einer Stakeholderanalyse? Zielgerichtete Maßnahmen für jeden Stakeholder-Typ

Aus der Analyse folgen spezifische Handlungsempfehlungen für jeden Stakeholder-Typ. Bei Opponents wird versucht, sie zu Promotors zu machen oder wenigstens die negative Wahrnehmung zu reduzieren. Promoters werden so beibehalten und als Promotoren genutzt. Skeptics werden informiert gehalten, während Supporters eingebunden und zu Change Champions, Support Speakern, Trainern oder Key Usern gemacht werden.

Besonders wertvoll ist Hollys Hinweis, Stakeholder untereinander wirken zu lassen: "Den Programmleiter zum Außenminister machen und den Rest der Firma von unserem Programm überzeugen.", wie sie es ausdrückte.

Praktische Take-aways für den Projektalltag

Holly fasste ihre Erkenntnisse in fünf zentralen Take-aways zusammen:

  • Augen auf für indirekt betroffene Stakeholder und das systemische Umfeld: Nicht nur die offensichtlich Betroffenen berücksichtigen, sondern auch das weitere Umfeld im Blick behalten.
  • Ergebnisse explizit vertraulich behandeln: Die Stakeholder-Analyse ist hochsensibel und darf nur mit den relevanten Personen geteilt werden.
  • Maßnahmen an die konkrete Projektsituation anpassen: Politik, Kultur und Organisation des Unternehmens müssen bei allen Aktivitäten berücksichtigt werden.
  • Stakeholder untereinander nutzen: Nicht nur direkte Beeinflussung planen, sondern auch den Einfluss von Stakeholdern untereinander strategisch einsetzen.
  • Überarbeitung regelmäßig einplanen: Die Stakeholder-Analyse und Engagement-Aktivitäten müssen zu festen Zeitpunkten aktiv überarbeitet werden, da sich Gegebenheiten kontinuierlich ändern.

Im Anschluss an den Impuls starteten wir die Diskussion mit den Teilnehmenden. Die lebhafte Diskussionsrunde brachte typische Projektherausforderungen zur Sprache.

Bei wiederholten Go-Live-Verschiebungen wenn Vertrauensverlust wegen mangelnder Verbindlichkeit entsteht, empfiehlt Holly zunächst zu prüfen, ob von der Projektleitung überhaupt Maßnahmen bestimmt werden, damit der nächste Go-Live-Termin gehalten werden kann.

Als Lösung setzt sie auf Ehrlichkeit: Gründe für die Verschiebung kommunizieren und aufzeigen, welche Maßnahmen ergriffen werden, um den nächsten Termin zu halten - beispielsweise Quality Gates. Gleichzeitig sollten Quick Wins und Meilensteine geteilt werden, die bereits erreicht wurden. Aktivitäten zur Vorbereitung wie Videos, Testimonials und positive Vibes können helfen. Eine erneute Stakeholderanalyse kann zusätzlich sinnvoll sein.

Für die Aufwandsschätzung für eine ordentliche Stakeholder Analyse nannte sie im Schnitt ca. 5-10 Arbeitstage, abhängig von der Projektgröße. Auf Seiten der Counterparts sollten ein paar Stunden mit der Projektleitung blockiert und Nachfolgetermine für Maßnahmen eingeplant werden.

Bei der Frage "Mit wem die Analyse durchführen?" zur Vermeidung von subjektiven Verzerrungen empfiehlt sie als erste Anlaufstelle immer die Projektleitung und OCM-Counterpart beim Unternehmen. "Alte Hasen" im Unternehmen können einen ersten, wenn auch subjektiven Blick geben. Einige Alteingesessene sollten vorsichtig und diplomatisch befragt werden, wobei Vertraulichkeit oberste Priorität hat.

KI-Unterstützung bei Stakeholder Analysen: Befragungen können mit KI ausgewertet werden, wobei Befragungen anonym durchgeführt werden sollten. Holly betonte dabei aber Datenschutzaspekte.

Bei der Frage, wieviele Informationen man wem mitgibt, gilt ihr Grundsatz: "Je emotionaler die Nachricht, desto direkter." Gerade wichtige Manager sollten einzeln abgeholt oder in einem Kick-off zusammengebracht werden. Solche Events können etwas locker gestaltet werden, damit die Emotionen positiv beeinflusst werden.

Zentrale Erkenntnisse für die Praxis

Die Kaffee Ecke verdeutlichte: Erfolgreiche SAP-Transformationen entstehen nicht durch perfekte Technik allein, sondern durch das systematische Verstehen und Einbinden aller relevanten Stakeholder. Hollys praxiserprobte Methoden und strukturierte Vorlagen bieten dafür eine solide Grundlage, die sich in verschiedenen Projektgrößen und -kontexten bewährt hat.

Besonders wertvoll waren ihre Hinweise zur vertraulichen Handhabung der Analyseergebnisse und die Betonung, dass Stakeholder-Management ein kontinuierlicher, iterativer Prozess ist, der regelmäßige Aufmerksamkeit und Anpassung erfordert.

 

Weiterführende Informationen:

- Informationen zur Kaffee-Ecken-Reihe: [go4.events.sap.com](https://go4.events.sap.com/eur-change-training-kaffee-ecke/de_de/home.html)- Nächste Session: Case Study zu Erfolgsfaktoren einer S/4HANA-Transformation bei Heidelberg Materials

- Informationen zu OCM Services der SAP https://www.sap.com/germany/cmp/oth/de-organizational-change-management/index.html

entry.title: Shipment cost: One truck, multiple stops
entry.content:
Dear All,

I have a requirement to allocate shipment cost for a group of shipments in one truck.  So for example, I have 2 deliveries for 2 different customers, 2 different shipments linked to those deliveries and one truck.  In all cases, the truck will have 2 shipments loaded. I have 2 stops with an extra charge for this, possibly 3 stops in the future. I want to know how I can track what deliveries/shipments are on that truck and drive my shipment cost calculation per shipment based on the number of drops and number of pallets . I have SAP S/4 HANA and basic LE-TRA. I dont have TM enabled and no handling units.

Could you please provide any guidance how to implement this?

Many thanks

entry.title: Vibe Coding with MCP Servers & SAP AI Core: Toward "Coding by Conversation"
entry.content:
Over the past few months, I’ve explored vibe coding — a workflow where you prompt the AI, it generates code, and you iterate. Fast and interactive, yes — but in enterprise projects, context and governance are critical. Without them, hallucinations and mismatched code structures quickly emerge.

This is where MCP servers (Model Context Protocol) and SAP AI Core become essential. Tools like fiori server and cap server allow AI assistants to understand your CDS models, Fiori metadata, and application structure — enabling contextual, reliable code generation.

In this blog, we’ll explore the architecture, practical usage, and enterprise best practices that make AI-assisted coding robust and production-ready.

What is Vibe Coding?

Vibe coding is a transformative approach to software development — essentially, coding by conversation.

  • You describe requirements in natural language.
  • The AI assistant interprets your intent and proposes code patches, scaffolding, or tests.
  • You review, refine, and approve the generated output.

The power of vibe coding lies in freeing developers from repetitive boilerplate tasks, allowing them to focus on high-value work like architecture, user experience, and business logic.

SAP’s reference architecture for vibe coding with Cline + SAP AI Core demonstrates how AI-assisted development can be safe, repeatable, and fully aligned with enterprise standards — turning AI from a helper into a structured development partner.

Core Principles from the SAP Architecture

From the reference architecture, five principles stand out:

  1. Prompt-Driven Development – Express features in natural language, and let the system automatically generate the initial scaffolding.
  2. Context Engineering – Supply LLMs with only the necessary structural context, such as APIs, CDS models, or MCP metadata.
  3. AI-Assisted Test-First Approach – Begin by generating tests, then guide the AI to produce code that fulfills those requirements.
  4. Human-in-the-Loop Governance – Developers retain responsibility for ensuring compliance, performance, and security.

Introducing MCP Servers

MCP (Model Context Protocol) acts as the bridge between your project and the AI assistant.

MCP (Model Context Protocol) is designed to act as a powerful bridge between your project and the AI assistant, ensuring that development is not just driven by prompts but also grounded in real project context. Instead of leaving the AI to guess or hallucinate about how your application is structured, MCP Servers provide it with a deep, contextual understanding of your project.

They expose key elements such as metadata, annotations, models, services, entities, relationships, and queries. This allows the AI to reason intelligently about your project’s architecture, whether it’s related to the user interface, the underlying data definitions, or the service layer.

With MCP servers running, your AI assistant doesn’t hallucinate blindly — it knows your project structure.

Architecture in Action: Cline + SAP AI Core + MCP

Here’s how the pieces fit:

  1. Cline –Your coding agent inside the IDE, mediating prompts, code diffs, and project changes.
  2. SAP AI Core – Hosts the foundation models (Claude, OpenAI, Gemini) in a governed, enterprise-ready environment.
  3. MCP Servers – mcp server expose structured context:
    • UI annotations, metadata, and manifest structure
    • Style guides and constraints
    • CDS entities and services

Workflow:

  • You prompt: “Create a ListReport for SalesOrder with a status field.”
  • AI (via MCP) inspects CDS models and annotations.
  • AI generates the CDS extension, Fiori annotations, and manifest changes.
  • You review, test, and deploy.

This architecture transforms AI coding from a “toy experiment” into a repeatable, enterprise-grade engineering practice.

How to Get SAP AI Core Credentials

  1. Access SAP BTP Cockpit: Go to your SAP BTP subaccount
  2. Navigate to AI Core: Services → Instances and Subscriptions → AI Core
  3. Create Service Key:
    • Go to your AI Core service instance
    • Create a new service key
    • Copy the credentials (clientid, clientsecret, url, serviceurls)
  4. Configure Authentication URL: Usually follows pattern https://{subdomain}.authentication.{region}.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
  5. Set Base URL: Typically https://api.ai.ml.hana.ondemand.com (check your service key for the exact URL)
SAP_AI_CORE_CLIENT_ID=your-client-id
SAP_AI_CORE_CLIENT_SECRET=your-client-secret
SAP_AI_CORE_AUTH_URL=https://your-subdomain.authentication.sap.hana.ondemand.com/oauth/token
SAP_AI_CORE_BASE_URL=https://base-ai-core-url
SAP_AI_CORE_RESOURCE_GROUP=your-resource-group

Refer to the screenshot below, which shows how we subscribed to the SAP AI Launchpad application to deploy our model according to the use case. We also created an SAP AI Core instance to obtain the necessary key details required for configuration in the Cline client.

Cline Configuration

  1. Install the Cline extension in VS Code
  2. Open Cline settings
  3. Configure these fields:
    • API Provider: Select "SAP AI Core"
    • Client ID: .clientid
    • Client Secret: .clientsecret
    • Base URL: .serviceurls.AI_API_URL
    • Auth URL: .url
    • AI Core Resource Group: Extract UUID from .appname (first part before the !)

       4. Test with a simple query to make sure it works

Add Server Configurations

To enable AI-assisted coding with full context, add the following server configurations to your cline_mcp_settings.json file. This configuration allows Cline to connect to the MCP servers that expose structured information about your project, including CDS models, Fiori metadata, manifest files, and coding style constraints. By providing these settings, you ensure that the AI assistant can:

  • Understand project structure: MCP servers give the AI visibility into your CDS entities, services, and UI annotations, allowing it to generate code that aligns with your existing models.
  • Follow enterprise standards: Style guides, naming conventions, and other constraints are passed through MCP servers, ensuring that generated code adheres to your organization’s best practices.
  • Generate context-aware code: Instead of generic snippets, the AI can create extensions, annotations, or manifests that fit seamlessly into your project.
  • Improve efficiency and reduce errors: By providing a structured context, the AI minimizes mismatches and hallucinations, letting developers focus on architecture, business logic, and user experience rather than repetitive boilerplate.

With the server configurations in place, Cline can interact with MCP servers in real time, making AI-assisted coding a safe, reliable, and enterprise-ready process.

{
  "mcpServers": {
    "cds-mcp": {
      "command": "cds-mcp",
      "args": [],
      "env": {},
    }
  }
}

Set Guardrails with Cline Rules (How-To)

Purpose: Provide persistent, project-level guidance — covering scope, coding style, documentation standards, and more — that’s always active in your workspace.

Cline Rules act as a continuous, automated advisor for your development team. By defining guardrails, you ensure that AI-assisted coding adheres to enterprise standards and project-specific conventions. This prevents inconsistent implementations, reduces technical debt, and maintains code quality across the team.

  1. Create a Rule File
    1. In Cline’s Rules tab, click “+” or use the command: /newrule.
    2. Save as a single file: .clinerules at the repo root, or use a folder-based setup .clinerules/ for multiple rules.
  2. Recommended Folder Structure
your-project/
├── .clinerules/
│   ├── 01-project.md      
│   ├── 02-coding.md
│   └── 03-documentation.md  
├── docs/
  • Each file addresses a specific aspect of project guidance: project scope, coding standards, and documentation expectations.

Example Prompt Flow

You: "Initialise an empty SAP CAP application in this folder."
AI: The empty CAP application has been successfully initialised in the current folder

 

You: "Generate an entities sales and sales order items"
AI: The entities is successfully created.

Result: you stay focused on implementing business logic and refining the user experience, while the AI assistant handles all the scaffolding, boilerplate, and repetitive code generation.

Open the Cline application and start the conversation with the above commands — this is where vibe coding truly comes alive, as your AI assistant (powered by MCP servers and SAP AI Core) begins generating context-aware code that you review, refine, and evolve into enterprise-ready solutions.

Once you select the Plan and submit the prompt, Cline (with MCP servers in the loop) interprets your intent, fetches the right CAP/Fiori context, and proposes structured code changes that you can review and refine into a production-ready solution.

You will now see a fully scaffolded CAP (Cloud Application Programming) application generated — with entities, services, and annotations created automatically based on your prompt, thanks to the MCP servers providing structured context to the AI assistant.

Benefits & Caution

Benefits

  • Faster Prototyping and Scaffolding – Quickly generate CAP entities, Fiori views, and annotations without manual boilerplate work.
  • Reduced Hallucinations – Structured context from MCP servers ensures AI proposals are relevant and accurate.
  • Freed Mental Bandwidth – Focus on UX, domain logic, and performance optimization, while AI handles repetitive scaffolding.
  • Aligned with SAP Standards & Governance – Generated code respects enterprise best practices and architectural guidelines.

Caution

  • MCP Servers Are Evolving – Always review AI-generated code before deployment.
  • Complex Business Logic Needs Oversight – Human expertise is essential for transactional integrity, security, and edge-case handling.
  • Prompt Precision Matters – Well-crafted prompts yield better, more reliable results.
  • Governance Remains Your Responsibility – Testing, security, and compliance cannot be fully delegated to AI.

Conclusion

Vibe coding isn’t just about writing code faster — it’s about reimagining how we build enterprise software. By combining AI assistants, SAP AI Core, and MCP servers, we provide AI the context it needs to act as a true development partner.

This approach lets developers move beyond boilerplate work and focus on what matters most: architecture, business logic, user experience, and innovation

Human expertise remains essential. Governance, compliance, performance tuning, and creativity stay firmly in the developer’s hands. But with vibe coding, tedious and repetitive tasks are no longer blockers — they’re delegated.

As these patterns mature, this may be remembered as the moment enterprise development evolved from “writing code” to “designing conversations.” The future of coding in SAP isn’t just AI-assisted — it’s context-aware, collaborative, and human-centered.

entry.title: Re: Depreciation KEY in Chart of Depr. 3710 (NL) does not...
entry.content:
Hello @Pieter_ 

Thank you for your question.

In S/4HANA Public Cloud, depreciation keys are country-specific and are preconfigured within the delivered Chart of Depreciation (CoD).

Each company code is automatically associated with its respective country's CoD, and this assignment cannot be altered.

This clarifies the reason for the different behaviour observed with the LINE key.

In CoD 3710 Netherlands, LINE is provided with a Base Value of 24 Net book value and Depreciation to the day, so the calculation is based on NBV.

In CoD 2510 (Belgium), LINE is provided with a Base Value of 01, Which Represents the Acquisition value, meaning depreciation is computed based on the initial acquisition cost.

This difference is intentional, since SAP provides CoD content that complies with local statutory and accounting standards.

In the Public Cloud, customers are unable to copy, redefine, or modify depreciation keys themselves. If your legal requirement in the Netherlands dictates the use of the Belgian variant (base 01), the supported approach is to raise an SAP support incident or submit a request via the Customer Influence Portal for SAP to provide an additional depreciation key in CoD 3710.

SAP Documentation References

SAP Help – Depreciation Keys in Asset Accounting (Public Cloud)

SAP Note 2723845 – Depreciation keys in S/4HANA Cloud(U-user login required)

SAP KBA 3593674 –Changing the depreciation key for different types of unposted assets results in varying outcomes - SAP S/4HANA Cloud Public Edition

entry.title: Re: Devtoberfest 2025 Contest Official Rules
entry.content:
@LuizSouza_L2D - I wish we could, but this determination is done by SAP legal.  Countries that are excluded are due to contest laws in that country that either explicitly exclude participation or that make it logistically impossible. Here's what I know specifically about Brazil:

In Brazil, what might look like a “contest” or giveaway in the U.S. often falls under “prize promotion / commercial promotion” rules. That means registration, authorization, and oversight by their government. 

The promoter must file for permission with the “Commercial Promotion Control System” (or equivalent) 40 to 120 days before the campaign starts. If you fail to comply (no authorization, break rules, etc.), you could be fined up to 100% of the prize value and banned from running promotions for up to 2 years. Also, there are “inspection fees” (basically regulatory fees) proportional to the prize value.

You almost certainly will need a Brazilian legal entity (or a partnership) to sponsor or own the promotion in Brazil so that the campaign can be “authorized” there. You’ll need to submit your paperwork 1–4 months in advance (in many cases 40–120 days before launch). Your marketing copy must fully comply with Brazil’s stringent consumer protection and advertising laws (clear disclosures, no misleading claims, etc.). You’ll need to pay inspection/regulatory fees and accept that penalty risk is high for noncompliance (including fines equal to the prize value or long bans). In practice, many international brands avoid including Brazil because of the hassle and risk. It’s not impossible — but it demands careful legal structure, local partnerships, and a willingness to endure bureaucracy and regulatory oversight.

entry.title: Any API to get all users which would respond positively to a given AUTHORITY-CHECK?
entry.content:
Hi,

In the flexible workflow, I'm asked to implement the method RESPONSIBILITY_RULE of the BAdI RSM_BADI_STATIC_RULE, to return the agents who have a given authorization e.g., AUTHORITY-CHECK 'ZZZZZ' FOR USER user ID field1 FIELD value1 ID field2 FIELD value2, etc. The workflow task can then be processed by any of these agents.

For information, our authorization values contain wildcards (values *, CX3101*) or are fixed (CX32). No intervals.

Is there any official (released) API which does that, or do you have any other recommendation?

I have searched a little bit:

  • The only API authorization query I know, CL_AUTH_OBJECTS_TO_SQL (cf. ABAP Keyword documentation) is not relevant for this query. It transforms some authorizations of the current user into a WHERE clause to select the values from a given database table (to avoid selecting all the lines and then removing the forbidden values by LOOP AT + AUTHORITY-CHECK).
  • The function module SUSR_GET_PROFS_WITH_SPEC_OBJCT (followed by LOOP AT + AUTHORITY-CHECK) can do the job but is not released and is a little bit slow. Its logic is:
    • All accesses to the database tables is without buffer
    • Get all the authorizations corresponding to the authorization object (USR12)
    • LOOP AT the authorizations
      • Get the profiles corresponding to these authorizations (UST10S)
    • Get the subprofiles of these profiles via FOR ALL ENTRIES (UST10C)
    • Get all the users corresponding to these profiles and subprofiles via FOR ALL ENTRIES (UST04)
  • Reading directly the database tables above, with a join. I just did a test and it's faster (with HANA)

Thanks.

Sandra

PS: my system is S/4HANA On Premises, ABAP 7.58.

entry.title: Free of Tax/Gross Up - retrospective
entry.content:
Hi

We occasionally have backdated changes to tax codes/NI category/FOT net salary etc.  We are seeing differences between the 'gross up' and tax and NI paid.  They should both offset each other to give zero difference.  For example, if the free of tax salary is £5000 per month, the gross up less the tax and NI should come to zero.  We are seeing the gross up be higher than the tax and NI, meaning the employee receives a higher net pay than they should.  How do you overcome this? 

 

Do you ensure the employee is on a non cumulative tax code?  So, even if HMRC issue a cumulative tax code, you process this tax code but on a M1 basis instead?

 

It is the SAp standard gross up function which we have, but backdated changes does not seem to be handled well?

 

TIA, 

Pauline

entry.title: Re: Any API to get all users which would respond positively to a given AUTHORITY-CHECK?
entry.content: I wouldn't expect authorizations to be changing that often so maybe making use of shared memory objects would fit in this instance given some mechanism to re-populate memory when associated security changes are made.
